title: Figma Launches Three AI-Powered Image Editing Tools to Streamline Design Workflows

paragraphs.content: Figma introduced three new AI-powered image editing tools—**Erase object**, **Isolate object**, and **Expand image**—on December 10, 2025, enabling designers to perform precise edits directly on the canvas without exporting to external software.The tools are now available in Figma Design and Figma Draw for users on Professional, Organization, and Enterprise plans with AI enabled.This update addresses a long-standing workflow friction point: the need to switch between multiple platforms for minor visual adjustments, from removing backgrounds to resizing assets for different marketing formats.Figma consolidated these new capabilities alongside existing features like Crop and Remove background into a revamped image editing toolbar, with background removal receiving prominent placement due to its frequent use among designers.

paragraphs.content: The launch coincides with Adobe announcing similar AI-powered image editing features within ChatGPT, highlighting a broader industry trend of embedding AI tools directly into creative workflows.Figma emphasizes that these tools operate without text prompts, prioritizing granular control and user agency over generative AI approaches that may flood workflows with suggestions.Industry analysts view the update as a strategic move positioning Figma beyond wireframing and prototyping toward a comprehensive visual design hub capable of handling production-level asset refinement.The company has confirmed plans to expand these tools across more Figma products in 2026, signaling confidence in their utility.

paragraphs.content: The **Erase object** tool allows designers to select unwanted elements using an improved lasso tool and remove them completely, eliminating the manual cleanup work previously requiring Photoshop or similar software.The **Isolate object** feature enables users to separate a subject from its background, then move it or apply effects like blur, lighting adjustments, desaturation, shadow enhancement, color correction, or focus adjustments while preserving the underlying image characteristics.The **Expand image** tool addresses a specific pain point for marketing teams: it extends image backgrounds to fit new aspect ratios without distortion, such as converting a square product photograph into a landscape web banner or mobile-optimized format.All three tools work directly on the Figma canvas, eliminating the traditional export-edit-reimport workflow that consumes designer time.

paragraphs.content: ContentGrip notes that these capabilities minimize "the common friction of jumping between platforms like Photoshop and Figma for minor visual tweaks," particularly benefiting marketers and product teams managing campaign mockups.For performance marketers testing variations, the tools enable faster turnaround without requiring design team intervention for every background cleanup or object repositioning task.Cross-functional design reviews also benefit, as stakeholders can now request and visualize small edits on the fly within a single file rather than waiting for revisions from design professionals.The absence of text prompt requirements makes these tools more accessible to non-expert users while maintaining the granular control that designers demand.

paragraphs.content: TechCrunch reports that Figma is "finally catching up" to established competitors like Adobe and Canva, which have offered object removal capabilities for several years.However, Figma's approach differentiates itself through seamless in-canvas workflow integration, reducing the friction of platform-switching that has long plagued creative teams.The timing of Figma's announcement—occurring the same day Adobe revealed AI image editing features within ChatGPT—underscores a strategic industry shift toward embedding AI capabilities at the point of user work rather than requiring separate tools.Figma was positioned as an October 2025 launch partner for ChatGPT's design features, though details regarding access to these new image tools through that integration remain unclear.

Figma's broader AI ecosystem contextualizes these image editing tools as part of a comprehensive creative platform evolving to handle generation, editing, and refinement tasks within a single workspace.The company emphasizes that generation models like Nano Banana excel at creating images from scratch, but precision editing requires granular, prompt-free tools—a gap these new features directly address.Looking forward, Figma's 2025 release notes position these tools among over 150 features launched throughout the year, with full platform expansion planned for 2026.Industry observers view this as a significant step toward reducing designer dependency on external software and accelerating design-to-production timelines for marketing and product teams.
